description: Mtatsminda Park is a historic amusement park perched atop Mount Mtatsminda (Holy Mountain) at 770 meters above sea level, offering breathtaking panoramic views of Tbilisi. With a history spanning over 100 years, the park combines thrilling rides, family entertainment, and natural beauty, making it one of Tbilisi's most beloved destinations. The park is accessible via a historic funicular railway that has been operating since 1905, adding to the nostalgic charm of this mountaintop retreat.
highlights: The iconic 80-meter-high Ferris wheel offering spectacular 360-degree views of Tbilisi
Historic funicular railway dating back to 1905, designed by Belgian engineer Alphonse Roby
Three distinct zones: extreme rides, kids' attractions, and family-friendly activities
Panoramic viewpoints perfect for photography, especially during golden hour and twilight
Diverse attractions including roller coasters, water slides, dark rides, and carousels
Close proximity to Mtatsminda Pantheon, the resting place of Georgia's most distinguished figures
Mamadaviti Church, a 19th-century domed church built on the site where St. David Garejeli lived in the 6th century
Clean, well-maintained facilities with numerous cafes and restaurants
The whimsical Bombora statue greeting visitors at the entrance
Tbilisi TV Tower visible from the park
tips: Visit in the late afternoon or evening to experience both daylight views and the magical city lights after sunset
Purchase a reloadable ride card at the entrance (costs 2 GEL for the card, then load with credit for rides ranging from 1-5 GEL each)
Take the funicular railway up (8 GEL) for a scenic journey, or consider hiking from Turtle Lake for the adventurous
Arrive early or later in the afternoon to avoid peak crowds, especially on weekends and during tourist season
Bring a camera - the views are spectacular and perfect for photography, particularly during golden hour
The funicular operates every 10 minutes from 9:00 AM to midnight; after 7:00 PM, it runs non-stop without middle station stops
Park entrance is free - you only pay for individual rides and attractions
Wear comfortable shoes if planning to explore the surrounding area or hike
Consider combining your visit with the Mtatsminda Pantheon and Mamadaviti Church nearby
The rope town costs 30 GEL if you're interested in this specific activity
Buses N90 and N124 from Rustaveli metro station also provide access if you prefer not to use the funicular
The park opens at noon on weekdays (11 AM on weekends) and stays open until 11 PM
vibe: Nostalgic, family-friendly, and enchanting - Mtatsminda Park offers a unique blend of Soviet-era charm and modern entertainment. The atmosphere is relaxed and joyful, with families, couples, and friends enjoying the rides and stunning views. As evening falls, the park transforms into a magical illuminated wonderland with twinkling lights and the glittering cityscape below. The historic funicular adds a sense of timelessness to the experience, while the diverse attractions ensure there's something for everyone. It's a place where locals and tourists alike come to escape the bustling city streets and enjoy a carefree day of fun and natural beauty.
expectations: A large, modern amusement park with state-of-the-art rides similar to Western theme parks
Easy, quick access without waiting times
Extensive dining options with international cuisine
A purely entertainment-focused destination without cultural or historical significance
reality: A charming mix of nostalgic Soviet-era attractions and renovated modern rides with more modest scale than Western mega-parks
The funicular can have queues during peak times; the 5-minute journey is part of the experience
Cafes and ice cream stands offer local Georgian snacks and refreshments rather than extensive restaurant options
The park sits on a culturally and spiritually significant mountain, home to the Pantheon and historic church, adding depth beyond entertainment
Family-friendly and moderate rides are the focus, with the main draw being the spectacular views rather than extreme thrills
unique_facts: Mtatsminda means 'Holy Mountain,' named after St. David Garejeli, one of the thirteen Assyrian Fathers who came to Georgia to preach Christianity in the 6th century
The funicular railway has been operating since 1905, making it over 115 years old and one of the oldest in the region
In the 1930s, Mtatsminda Park was the 3rd most visited public park in the entire Soviet Union, surpassed only by Moscow's Gorky Park
The park's nickname 'Bombora' comes from a beloved Soviet-era Georgian cartoon character - a playful giant child symbolizing fun and wonder

The Mtatsminda Pantheon nearby is the final resting place of 53 distinguished Georgian personalities, including Alexander Griboyedov, the Russian writer and diplomat, and his Georgian wife Nino Chavchavadze
The first church on Mount Mtatsminda was built at the end of the 6th century; the current Mamadaviti Church dates from 1859-1871
After the Soviet collapse, the park languished until 2007 when local businessman and philanthropist sponsored complete revitalization
The mountain was originally chosen for a planned 'Upper Tbilisi' residential development in 1905, but was converted into a landscaped park in the late 1930s instead
The tradition of naming the mountain 'Holy' follows Georgian custom of naming Christian sites after sacred places in Greece and Palestine
St. David Garejeli carved a cave in the rock where he lived on this mountain before moving to establish the famous David Gareja Monastery complex near the Georgian-Azerbaijani border
surprises: The park entrance is completely free - you only pay for rides you choose to experience
The views from the Ferris wheel and viewpoints are genuinely breathtaking, rivaling or exceeding expectations, especially at sunset and night
The historic funicular is an attraction in itself, not just transportation, offering spectacular ascending views of Tbilisi
The park successfully balances nostalgia with modern updates, preserving its Soviet-era charm while offering well-maintained, safe attractions
The cultural and spiritual significance of the location adds unexpected depth - you can visit an amusement park, a writers' pantheon, and a historic church all in one trip
Locals are as enthusiastic about visiting as tourists, making it a genuine part of Tbilisi life rather than just a tourist trap
The whimsical Bombora statue and other Soviet-era touches create a unique atmosphere you won't find in Western amusement parks
The park is remarkably clean and well-maintained despite its age, showing pride in preservation
You can hike to the park from Turtle Lake if you want to combine nature walking with amusement park fun
The evening transformation is dramatic - the park comes alive with lights and energy after dark, creating a completely different ambiance than daytime visits

historical_background.origins: In 1905, Belgian engineer Alphonse Roby designed a 500-meter-long funicular railway to connect lower Tbilisi with a planned 'Upper Tbilisi' residential development atop Mount Mtatsminda. When those plans didn't materialize, the area was converted into a landscaped park in the late 1930s.
historical_background.soviet_era: During the Soviet period, Mtatsminda Park became immensely popular, ranking as the 3rd most visited public park in the entire Soviet Union. The park featured rides and attractions that entertained generations of Georgian families.
historical_background.post_soviet_decline: Following the collapse of the Soviet Union and Georgia's independence, the park fell into disrepair and languished for years due to economic difficulties.
historical_background.modern_revival: In 2007, a major revitalization project funded by a local businessman and philanthropist transformed the park into a modern amusement complex. An 80-meter Ferris wheel became the new centerpiece, and the entire facility was upgraded while maintaining its nostalgic character.
historical_background.religious_significance: The mountain's name 'Mtatsminda' (Holy Mountain) derives from St. David Garejeli, one of the thirteen Assyrian Fathers who brought Christianity to Georgia in the 6th century. He lived in a cave carved into the mountainside. The first church was built in the late 6th century, with the current Mamadaviti Church constructed between 1859-1871.

practical_information.location: Mount Mtatsminda, 770 meters above sea level, highest point in Tbilisi

funicular.location: Lower station is 1 km from Rustaveli Avenue, 10-minute uphill walk from Opera and Ballet Theatre
funicular.schedule: 09:00 - midnight (some sources cite 09:45 AM - 11:30 PM in summer, noon - 9:00 PM in winter)
funicular.cost: 2 GEL for plastic card (non-refundable) + 3 GEL per boarding (previously cited as 8 GEL for ride)
funicular.note: After 7:00 PM, middle station is bypassed for non-stop service

access.bus: Routes N90 and N124 from Rustaveli metro station
access.hiking: Trail from Chonkadze Street takes approximately one hour; trail from Turtle Lake is also available
access.cable_car: Alternative access costing 12 GEL with stunning views

practical_information.best_time_to_visit: Late afternoon into evening for optimal lighting, sunset views, and city lights. Golden hour and twilight are particularly magical. Weekdays or early/late hours on weekends to avoid crowds.
nearby_attractions: Mtatsminda Pantheon (cemetery of distinguished Georgian figures)
